cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Information obtain type
cdes.definitionDescription: The type as related to how the information was obtained.
cdes.instructions: Note: The scale presented here is not based on the original article. It has become common practice in clinical trial administration to use this modified version that places the scores in reverse order (i.e.,  good recovery  = 1,  moderate disability  =2, etc.).

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Consciousness indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator related to ability of the head-injured child to obey simple commands or say any words. For younger children, indicates ability to act/react/interact beyond reflexes.
cdes.questionText: Is the head-injured person able to obey simple commands or say any words? For younger patients, can he or she act/react/interact beyond reflexes?
cdes.instructions:
If No, register Vegetative State (VS)  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 7.

An individual who shows the ability to obey even simple commands or utter any word or communicate specifically in any other way is no longer considered to be in a vegetative state. Eye movements are not reliable evidence of meaningful responsiveness; corroborate with nursing staff and the childӳ parents when possible. Confirmation of VS requires full assessment as in the Royal College of Physician Guidelines. However, for infants, actively following the movement of a parent or people/object with eyes, grasping for objects, making faces, etc. are interactions; breast feeding and crying continuously can be reflexes.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Assistance home requirement indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the assistance of another person at home is essential for some activities of daily living. For younger children, indicates if the child is dependent upon a caretaker more than it is expected based on age.
cdes.questionText: Is the assistance of another person at home essential every day for some activities of daily living? For younger patients, is the child dependent upon a caretaker more so than is expected based on age?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, go to 2b. If No, skip to 3.

For an older child, complete independence and a ҮoҠanswer should mean that the person can get washed, put on clean clothes without prompting, prepare food for themselves, deal with callers, and handle minor domestic crises. The person should be able to carry out activities without needing prompting or reminding, and should be capable of being left alone for an age appropriate period. Young children should be able to accomplish age appropriate developmental milestones without assistance (see Vineland Daily Living Skills). If a child compensates for physical disability to the point where developmental milestones are only mildly compromised, question parents to determine the level of independence (i.e., a child with a hemiparesis who is still able to complete tasks that other children of that age can be rated as independent).
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Frequent assistance home need indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the child needs frequent help or for someone to be around at home most of the time.  For younger children, indicates that the child needs frequent help from a caretaker to accomplish tasks relevant for his/her age.
cdes.questionText: Does the child need frequent help or for someone to be around at home most of the time? For younger patients, does the child need frequent help from a caretaker to accomplish tasks that a child this age should be able to accomplish (If child sometimes functions at an age appropriate level, then answer 'yes.')
cdes.instructions:
If child sometimes functions at an age appropriate level, then answer Yes. If Yes, register Lower Severe Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 6. If No, register Upper Severe Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 5.

For an older child, complete independence and a ҮoҠanswer should mean that the person can get washed, put on clean clothes without prompting, prepare food for themselves, deal with callers, and handle minor domestic crises. The person should be able to carry out activities without needing prompting or reminding, and should be capable of being left alone for an age appropriate period. Young children should be able to accomplish age appropriate developmental milestones without assistance (see Vineland Daily Living Skills). If a child compensates for physical disability to the point where developmental milestones are only mildly compromised, question parents to determine the level of independence (i.e., a child with a hemiparesis who is still able to complete tasks that other children of that age can be rated as independent).
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Shop travel without assistance indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the child is able to shop and travel without assistance. For younger children, indicates if the child behave age appropriately outside the home.
cdes.questionText: Is the child able to shop and travel without assistance? For younger patients, does the child behave age appropriately outside the home?
cdes.instructions:
If yes, skip to 4. If No, register Upper Severe Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 5.

This item considers activities such as shopping and traveling, always in the context of age appropriate behaviors.  This includes being able to plan what to buy, take care of money, and behave appropriately in public. The individual need not normally shop, but must be able to do so. A younger child must behave age appropriately in public.  An older child may drive or use public transit to get around. Ability to use a taxi is sufficient, provided the person can phone for it themselves and give instruction the driver.  Older children who sometimes were allowed to travel independently before the injury should be able to walk to a neighborӳ house, take a school bus, ride a bike, or take public transportation.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Current work school function pre-injury capacity indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the child can function at work or in school at their previous capacity.
cdes.questionText: Can the child function at work or in school at his or her previous capacity?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, skip to 5. If No, go to 4b.

If an adolescent was working before the injury, then his or her current capacity for work should be at the same level. If the individual was seeking work before, then the injury should not have adversely affected chances of obtaining work or the level of work for which he or she is eligible. If the patient was in preschool or a student before the injury, then capacity for school work and school activities should not be adversely affected.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Work school restriction indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates restrictions that apply to childӳ ability to work and study, including  ability to work only in a sheltered workshop or non-competitive job, in a school setting for severely impaired children or tutored at home, or currently unable to work or go to school.
cdes.questionText: Level of restriction: i) Able to work only in a sheltered workshop or non-competitive job, in a school setting for severely impaired children or tutored at home, or currently unable to work or go to school.
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, register Lower Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 4.  If No, go to 4bii.

If an adolescent was working before the injury, then his or her current capacity for work should be at the same level. If the individual was seeking work before, then the injury should not have adversely affected chances of obtaining work or the level of work for which he or she is eligible. If the patient was in preschool or a student before the injury, then capacity for school work and school activities should not be adversely affected.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Reduced work school capacity indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates reduced work or school capacity for an injured child.
cdes.questionText: School/work level of restriction: ii) Reduced work or school capacity
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, register Upper Moderate Disability and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 3.   If No, go to 5.

If an adolescent was working before the injury, then his or her current capacity for work should be at the same level. If the individual was seeking work before, then the injury should not have adversely affected chances of obtaining work or the level of work for which he or she is eligible. If the patient was in preschool or a student before the injury, then capacity for school work and school activities should not be adversely affected.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Current participation social leisure activity pre-injury indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the child is able to resume regular social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Is the child able to resume regular social and leisure activities?
cdes.instructions:
If yes, skip to 6. If No, go to 5b.

The individual may not have resumed all previous leisure activities, but should not be prevented from doing so by physical or mental impairment. If he or she has stopped the majority of activities because of loss of interest or motivation, then this is considered a disability. For younger children, social and leisure activities can include games and toys played with caretakers, siblings or other children as well as the ability to interact in a playful manner with others.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent restriction social leisure activity unable participate indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator related to being unable to participate in social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Unable to participate: Rarely, if ever, take part
cdes.instructions:
Module: What is the extent of restrictions on social and leisure activities?

cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator related to being much less able to participate in social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Participate much less: Less than half as often.
cdes.instructions:
Module: What is the extent of restrictions on social and leisure activities?

If Yes, register Upper Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 3.  If No, go to 5biii.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent restriction social leisure activity little decrease participation indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator related to a bit less participate in social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Participate a bit less: At least half as often as before injury.
cdes.instructions:
Module: What is the extent of restrictions on social and leisure activities?

If Yes, register Lower Good Recovery  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 2.  If No, skip to 6.

The individual may not have resumed all previous leisure activities, but should not be prevented from doing so by physical or mental impairment. If he or she has stopped the majority of activities because of loss of interest or motivation, then this is considered a disability. For younger children, social and leisure activities can include games and toys played with caretakers, siblings or other children as well as the ability to interact in a playful manner with others.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Family friendship psychological problem indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if there are psychological problems that have resulted in ongoing disruption with respect to either family or friendships
cdes.questionText: Are there psychological problems that have resulted in ongoing disruption with respect to either family or friendships?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, go to 6b. If No, skip to 7.

Typical post-traumatic personality changes: quick temper, irritability, anxiety, aggressive acts, insensitivity to others, mood swings, depression, and unreasonable or childish behavior that is not age appropriate

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent disruption family friendship type
cdes.definitionDescription: The extent of disruption or strain in family and friendship due to injury.
cdes.questionText: What is the extent of disruption or strain?
cdes.permissibleValue: Occasional - less than weekly;Unknown;Constant - daily and intolerable;Frequent - once a week or more, but tolerable;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Occasional - less than weekly;Unknown;Constant - daily and intolerable;Frequent - once a week or more, but tolerable;
cdes.instructions: If  ԃonstant ֠daily and intolerableԬ  register Lower Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 4.  If Ԇrequent ֠once a week or more, but tolerableԬ register Upper Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 3.  If ԏccasional ֠less than weeklyԬ register Lower Good Recovery and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 2.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Return normal life other problem indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator related to other problem in returning to normal life.
cdes.questionText: Are there any other problems relating to the injury that affect daily life?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, register Lower Good Recovery  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 2.  If No, register Upper Good Recovery  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 1.

Typical problems reported after head injury: headaches, dizziness, tiredness, sensitivity to noise or light, slowness, memory failures, concentration problems, or other problems.

cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant, as a part of the Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (PGOSE).
cdes.permissibleDescription: Death;Vegetative State (VS);Lower Severe Disability (Lower SD);Upper Severe Disability (Upper SD);Lower Moderate Disability (Lower MD);Upper Moderate Disability (Upper MD);Lower Good Recovery (Lower GR);Upper Good Recovery (Upper GR);
cdes.instructions: Note: The scale presented here is not based on the original article. It has become common practice in clinical trial administration to use this modified version that places the scores in reverse order (i.e.,  good recovery  = 1,  moderate disability  =2, etc.).

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended, Pediatric Revision (GOS-E Peds) - date time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date and time that the participant performed the Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale extended version, as a part of Pediatric Glasgow Coma Scale Extended (PGOSE).
cdes.questionText: Date and time of Glasgow Outcome Scale -Extended, Pediatric Revision
cdes.instructions:
Data Sharing Instructions: When date/time data are prepared for aggregation or sharing they should be converted to the format specified by ISO 8601, YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.

Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Current work school function pre-injury capacity indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the child can function at work or in school at their previous capacity.
cdes.questionText: Can the child function at work or in school at his or her previous capacity?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, skip to 5. If No, go to 4b.

If an adolescent was working before the injury, then his or her current capacity for work should be at the same level. If the individual was seeking work before, then the injury should not have adversely affected chances of obtaining work or the level of work for which he or she is eligible. If the patient was in preschool or a student before the injury, then capacity for school work and school activities should not be adversely affected.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Work school restriction indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates restrictions that apply to childӳ ability to work and study, including  ability to work only in a sheltered workshop or non-competitive job, in a school setting for severely impaired children or tutored at home, or currently unable to work or go to school.
cdes.questionText: Level of restriction: i) Able to work only in a sheltered workshop or non-competitive job, in a school setting for severely impaired children or tutored at home, or currently unable to work or go to school.
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, register Lower Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 4.  If No, go to 4bii.

If an adolescent was working before the injury, then his or her current capacity for work should be at the same level. If the individual was seeking work before, then the injury should not have adversely affected chances of obtaining work or the level of work for which he or she is eligible. If the patient was in preschool or a student before the injury, then capacity for school work and school activities should not be adversely affected.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Reduced work school capacity indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates reduced work or school capacity for an injured child.
cdes.questionText: School/work level of restriction: ii) Reduced work or school capacity
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, register Upper Moderate Disability and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 3.   If No, go to 5.

If an adolescent was working before the injury, then his or her current capacity for work should be at the same level. If the individual was seeking work before, then the injury should not have adversely affected chances of obtaining work or the level of work for which he or she is eligible. If the patient was in preschool or a student before the injury, then capacity for school work and school activities should not be adversely affected.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Current participation social leisure activity pre-injury indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if the child is able to resume regular social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Is the child able to resume regular social and leisure activities?
cdes.instructions:
If yes, skip to 6. If No, go to 5b.

The individual may not have resumed all previous leisure activities, but should not be prevented from doing so by physical or mental impairment. If he or she has stopped the majority of activities because of loss of interest or motivation, then this is considered a disability. For younger children, social and leisure activities can include games and toys played with caretakers, siblings or other children as well as the ability to interact in a playful manner with others.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent restriction social leisure activity unable participate indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator related to being unable to participate in social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Unable to participate: Rarely, if ever, take part
cdes.instructions:
Module: What is the extent of restrictions on social and leisure activities?

If Yes, register Lower Moderate Disability and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 4.  If No, go to 5bii.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent restriction social leisure activity much decrease participation indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator related to being much less able to participate in social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Participate much less: Less than half as often.
cdes.instructions:
Module: What is the extent of restrictions on social and leisure activities?

If Yes, register Upper Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 3.  If No, go to 5biii.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent restriction social leisure activity little decrease participation indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator related to a bit less participate in social and leisure activities.
cdes.questionText: Participate a bit less: At least half as often as before injury.
cdes.instructions:
Module: What is the extent of restrictions on social and leisure activities?

If Yes, register Lower Good Recovery  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 2.  If No, skip to 6.

The individual may not have resumed all previous leisure activities, but should not be prevented from doing so by physical or mental impairment. If he or she has stopped the majority of activities because of loss of interest or motivation, then this is considered a disability. For younger children, social and leisure activities can include games and toys played with caretakers, siblings or other children as well as the ability to interact in a playful manner with others.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Family friendship psychological problem indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if there are psychological problems that have resulted in ongoing disruption with respect to either family or friendships
cdes.questionText: Are there psychological problems that have resulted in ongoing disruption with respect to either family or friendships?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, go to 6b. If No, skip to 7.

Typical post-traumatic personality changes: quick temper, irritability, anxiety, aggressive acts, insensitivity to others, mood swings, depression, and unreasonable or childish behavior that is not age appropriate
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Extent disruption family friendship type
cdes.definitionDescription: The extent of disruption or strain in family and friendship due to injury.
cdes.questionText: What is the extent of disruption or strain?
cdes.permissibleValue: Occasional - less than weekly;Unknown;Constant - daily and intolerable;Frequent - once a week or more, but tolerable;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Occasional - less than weekly;Unknown;Constant - daily and intolerable;Frequent - once a week or more, but tolerable;
cdes.instructions: If  ԃonstant ֠daily and intolerableԬ  register Lower Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 4.  If Ԇrequent ֠once a week or more, but tolerableԬ register Upper Moderate Disability  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 3.  If ԏccasional ֠less than weeklyԬ register Lower Good Recovery and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 2.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Return normal life other problem indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: The indicator related to other problem in returning to normal life.
cdes.questionText: Are there any other problems relating to the injury that affect daily life?
cdes.instructions:
If Yes, register Lower Good Recovery  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 2.  If No, register Upper Good Recovery  and skip to end of form and record GOS-E Peds Score = 1.

Typical problems reported after head injury: headaches, dizziness, tiredness, sensitivity to noise or light, slowness, memory failures, concentration problems, or other problems.
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Glasgow Outcome Scale Extended (GOSE) Pediatric Revision

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (GOS-E Peds) - Score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant, as a part of the Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended (PGOSE).
cdes.permissibleDescription: Death;Vegetative State (VS);Lower Severe Disability (Lower SD);Upper Severe Disability (Upper SD);Lower Moderate Disability (Lower MD);Upper Moderate Disability (Upper MD);Lower Good Recovery (Lower GR);Upper Good Recovery (Upper GR);
cdes.instructions: Note: The scale presented here is not based on the original article. It has become common practice in clinical trial administration to use this modified version that places the scores in reverse order (i.e.,  good recovery  = 1,  moderate disability  =2, etc.).
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

cdes.cdeName: Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale - Extended, Pediatric Revision (GOS-E Peds) - date time
cdes.definitionDescription: Date and time that the participant performed the Pediatric Glasgow Outcome Scale extended version, as a part of Pediatric Glasgow Coma Scale Extended (PGOSE).
cdes.questionText: Date and time of Glasgow Outcome Scale -Extended, Pediatric Revision
cdes.instructions:
Data Sharing Instructions: When date/time data are prepared for aggregation or sharing they should be converted to the format specified by ISO 8601, YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.

Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.referrences: Beers SR, Wisniewski SR, Garcia-Filion P, Tian Y, Hahner T, Berger RP, Bell MJ, Adelson PD. Validity of a pediatric version of the Glasgow Outcome Scale-Extended.  J Neurotrauma. 2012 Apr 10;29(6):1126-39. Epub 2012 Apr 10.

description: the individual is asked to complete a self-explanatory, brief four-item query of usual leisure-time exercise habits.

cdes.cdeName: Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire - strenuous exercise per week frequency
cdes.definitionDescription: Numeric value counting the average number of times per week that a participant/subject reports doing strenuous exercise (e.g., running, jogging, hockey, football, soccer, squash, basketball, cross country skiing, judo, roller skating, vigorous swimming, vigorous long distance bicycling)
cdes.instructions: Record the appropriate number of times per week. Lead question: During a typical 7-day period (a week), how many times on the average do you do the following kinds of exercise for more than 15 minutes during your free time
cdes.referrences:
Godin G, Shephard RJ. Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire. Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise. 29 June Supplement:S36-S38, 1997
Godin G, Shephard RJ. A simple method to assess exercise behavior in the community. Can J Appl Sport Sci. 10(3):141-6, 1985

cdes.cdeName: Goniometry shoulder measurement
cdes.definitionDescription: Measurement in degrees of the passive range of motion for shoulder abduction.
cdes.instructions:
Assess passive range of motion (ROM) for shoulder abduction, measured to nearest 5 degrees using standard goniometry techniques.

•  Requires assessment by a trained person (such as a physical therapist)
 o  Estimated time per person is 5 minutes
 o  Need a goniometer 
 o  Limitations—requires a trained specialist
cdes.referrences: No references available

description: A manipulative dexterity test; requires more complex visual-motor coordination than most pegboards

cdes.cdeName: Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) - Dominant hand time duration
cdes.definitionDescription: Duration of time for hand to place pegs as part of Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT)
cdes.instructions: This is a pegboard and these are the pegs. Examiner points out each and then picks up one of the pegs and continues.) All the pegs are the same. They have a groove, that is, a round side and a square side and so do the holes in the boards. What you must do is match the groove of the peg with the groove of the board and put these pegs into the holes like this. (The examiner demonstrates by filling the top row. Remove the pegs, putting them back into the tray.) When I say go, begin here and put the pegs into the boards as fast as you can, using only your (dominant) hand. Fill the top row completely from this side to this side. Do not skip any; fill each row the same way you filled the top row. Any questions? Ready, as fast as you can, go.
cdes.referrences: http://www.si-instruments.com/supplier/files/download/lafayette-current-version-grooved-pegboard-test-32025-lafayette-32025-grooved-pegboard-test-manual-pdf.html

cdes.cdeName: Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT) - Dominant hand pegs placed correctly count
cdes.definitionDescription: Number of pegs placed correctly during hand test, as part of Grooved Pegboard Test (GPT)
cdes.instructions: This is a pegboard and these are the pegs. Examiner points out each and then picks up one of the pegs and continues.) All the pegs are the same. They have a groove, that is, a round side and a square side and so do the holes in the boards. What you must do is match the groove of the peg with the groove of the board and put these pegs into the holes like this. (The examiner demonstrates by filling the top row. Remove the pegs, putting them back into the tray.) When I say go, begin here and put the pegs into the boards as fast as you can, using only your (dominant) hand. Fill the top row completely from this side to this side. Do not skip any; fill each row the same way you filled the top row. Any questions? Ready, as fast as you can, go.

description: The Side Effects Scale (Hague) assess possible side-effects of medications for epilepsy, to be completed by a parent/guardian.

cdes.cdeName: Hague Side Effects Scale (HASES) - drowsiness sleepiness scale
cdes.definitionDescription: The reported level of severity of drowsiness and sleepiness noticed by a guardian following administration of antiepileptic medication in a participant/subject during the past 3 months according to Hague Side Effects Scale (HASES).
cdes.instructions: Have you noticed any of the following side-effects of antiepileptic medication in your child during the past 3 months?
cdes.referrences: Carpay JA, et al. Parent-reported subjective complaints in children using antiepileptic drugs: what do they mean? Epilepsy & Behavior. 2002; 3: 322-29.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

description: Contains data elements which rate the severity of the participant/subject's level of anxiety. (Examples of CDEs included: Anxious mood; Tension; Fears; etc.)

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A) - anxious mood score
cdes.definitionDescription: The score of the participant's/subject's anxious mood, as part of the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HAM-A) form.
cdes.questionText: Anxious Mood Worries anticipation of the worst fearful anticipation irritability.
cdes.instructions: Rate the patients by finding the answer which best describes the extent to which he/she has these conditions.  Select one of the five responses for each of the fourteen questions.
cdes.referrences: The HAM-A is in the public domain.  Hamilton M. The assessment of anxiety states by rating. Br J Medical Psychology 1959; 32: 50-55.  Leentjens AFG et al. Anxiety rating scales in Parkinson's disease: a validation study of the Hamilton Anxiety Scale, the Beck Anxiety Inventory and the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale. In review.  Shear MK, Vander BJ, Rucci P, Endicott J, Lydiard B, Otto MW et al (2001): Reliability and validity of a structured interview guide for the Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (SIGH-A). Depress.Anxiety. 13: 166-178.  Leentjens AFG et al. Anxiety Rating Scales in Parkinson's Disease: Critique and Recommendations, Mov Disord 2008; 23 (14): 2015-2025.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

description: This measure is considered the gold standard in depression research and is widely used. It is common in antidepressant drug trials but is not systematically used in ALS trials.

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - depressed mood indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for whether, how, and in what circumstances the participant/subject expresses feelings of depression (sadness, hopeless, helpless, worthless), as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Absent;These feeling states indicated only on questioning;These feeling states spontaneously reported verbally;Communicates feeling states non-verbally, i.e. through facial expression, posture, voice and tendency to weep;Patient reports virtually only these feeling states in his/her spontaneous verbal and non-verbal communication;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - guilty mind indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the presence, qualities, and strength of the participant/subject's guilty feelings, if any, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Absent;Self reproach, feels he/she has let people down;Ideas of guilt or rumination over past errors or sinful deeds;Present illness is a punishment. Delusions of guilt;Hears accusatory or denunciatory voices and/or experiences threatening visual hallucinations;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - suicide indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the presence, qualities, and strength of the participant/subject's suicide-relevant thoughts and actions , if any, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Absent;Feels life is not worth living;Wishes he/she were dead or any thoughts of possible death to self;Ideas or gestures of suicide;Attempts at suicide (any serious attempt rate 4);
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - early night insomnia indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with early-night insomnia, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty falling asleep;Complains of occasional difficulty falling asleep, i.e. more than 1/2 hour;Complains of nightly difficulty falling asleep;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - middle night insomnia indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with middle-night insomnia, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Complains of being restless and disturbed during the night;Waking during the night - any getting out of bed rates 2 (except for purposes of voiding);
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with insomnia in the early morning hours, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Insomnia: early hours of the morning
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Waking in early hours of the morning but goes back to sleep;Unable to fall asleep again if he/she gets out of bed;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - work activities difficulty indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with work and activities, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Thoughts and feelings of incapacity, fatigue or weakness related to activities, work or hobbies;Loss of interest in activity, hobbies, or work - either directly reported by the patient or indirect in listlessness, indecision and vacillation (feels he/she has to push self to work or activities);Decrease in actual time spent in activities or decrease in productivity. Rate 3 if the patient does not spend at least three hours a day in activities (job or hobbies) excluding routine chores;Stopped working because of present illness. Rate 4 if patient engages in no activities except routine chores, or if patient fails to perform routine chores unassisted.;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.

cdes.questionText: Retardation (slowness of thought and speech, impaired ability to concentrate, decreased motor activity)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Normal speech and thought;Slight retardation during the interview;Obvious retardation during the interview;Interview difficult;Complete stupor;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).

cdes.permissibleDescription: None;Fidgetiness;Playing with hands, hair, etc;Moving about, can't sit still;Hand wringing, nail biting, hair-pulling, biting of lips;

cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Subjective tension and irritability;Worrying about minor matters;Apprehensive attitude apparent in face or speech;Fears expressed without questioning;

cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the intensity of the participant/subject's somatic gastrointestinal symptoms, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - guilty mind indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the presence, qualities, and strength of the participant/subject's guilty feelings, if any, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Absent;Self reproach, feels he/she has let people down;Ideas of guilt or rumination over past errors or sinful deeds;Present illness is a punishment. Delusions of guilt;Hears accusatory or denunciatory voices and/or experiences threatening visual hallucinations;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - suicide indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the presence, qualities, and strength of the participant/subject's suicide-relevant thoughts and actions , if any, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Absent;Feels life is not worth living;Wishes he/she were dead or any thoughts of possible death to self;Ideas or gestures of suicide;Attempts at suicide (any serious attempt rate 4);
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - early night insomnia indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with early-night insomnia, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty falling asleep;Complains of occasional difficulty falling asleep, i.e. more than 1/2 hour;Complains of nightly difficulty falling asleep;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - middle night insomnia indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with middle-night insomnia, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Complains of being restless and disturbed during the night;Waking during the night - any getting out of bed rates 2 (except for purposes of voiding);
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - early morning insomnia indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with insomnia in the early morning hours, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Insomnia: early hours of the morning
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Waking in early hours of the morning but goes back to sleep;Unable to fall asleep again if he/she gets out of bed;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - work activities difficulty indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's difficulty, if any, with work and activities, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Thoughts and feelings of incapacity, fatigue or weakness related to activities, work or hobbies;Loss of interest in activity, hobbies, or work - either directly reported by the patient or indirect in listlessness, indecision and vacillation (feels he/she has to push self to work or activities);Decrease in actual time spent in activities or decrease in productivity. Rate 3 if the patient does not spend at least three hours a day in activities (job or hobbies) excluding routine chores;Stopped working because of present illness. Rate 4 if patient engages in no activities except routine chores, or if patient fails to perform routine chores unassisted.;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - retardation indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for any retardation in the participant/subject's mental or physical behavior, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Retardation (slowness of thought and speech, impaired ability to concentrate, decreased motor activity)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Normal speech and thought;Slight retardation during the interview;Obvious retardation during the interview;Interview difficult;Complete stupor;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - agitation indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the extent of agitated behaviors the participant/subject displays, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: None;Fidgetiness;Playing with hands, hair, etc;Moving about, can't sit still;Hand wringing, nail biting, hair-pulling, biting of lips;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - anxiety psychic difficulty indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's degree of psychic anxiety, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: No difficulty;Subjective tension and irritability;Worrying about minor matters;Apprehensive attitude apparent in face or speech;Fears expressed without questioning;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - anxiety somatic indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's grade of symptoms of somatic anxiety, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Anxiety somatic (physiological concomitantsof anxiety) such as: gastro-intestinal - dry mouth, wind, indigestion, diarrhea, cramps, belching; cardio-vascular - palpitations, headaches; respiratory - hyperventilation, sighing; urinary frequency; sweating
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - somatic symptoms indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the intensity of the participant/subject's somatic gastrointestinal symptoms, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: None;Loss of appetite but eating without staff encouragement. Heavy feelings in abdomen;Difficulty eating without staff urging. Requests or requires laxatives or medication for bowels or medication for gastro-intestinal symptoms;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - general somatic symptoms indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the intensity of the participant/subject's general somatic symptoms, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: None;Heaviness in limbs, back, or head. Backaches, headaches, muscle aches. Loss of energy and fatigability;Any clear-cut symptom rates 2;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - genital symptoms indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the intensity of the participant/subject's genital symptoms such as loss of libido or menstrual disturbances, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Genital symptoms(symptoms such as loss of libido, menstrual disturbances)
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - hypochondriasis indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the intensity of the participant/subject's hypochondriasis, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Not present;Self-absorption (bodily);Preoccupation with health;Frequent complaints, requests for help, etc;Hypochondriacal delusions;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - weight loss patient indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the amount of weight loss reported by the participant/subject, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Loss of weight according to the patient
cdes.permissibleDescription: No weight loss;Probable weight loss associated with present illness;Definite (according to patient) weight loss;Not assessed;
cdes.instructions: Rate either HDRS Q16a or HDRSQ16b
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - weight loss measurement indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the amount of the participant/subject's weight loss according to weekly measurements, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.questionText: Loss of weight according to weekly measurements
cdes.permissibleDescription: Less than 1 lb weight loss in week;Greater than 1 lb weight loss in week;Greater than 2 lb weight loss in week;Not assessed;
cdes.instructions: Rate either HDRS Q16a or HDRSQ16b
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - insight indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the participant/subject's acknowledgement of depression and illness, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)
cdes.permissibleDescription: Acknowledges being depressed and ill;Acknowledges illness but attributes cause to bad food, climate, overwork, virus, need for rest, etc;Denies being ill at all;
cdes.instructions: for each item select the one “cue” which best characterizes the patient. Be sure to record the answers in the appropriate spaces (positions 0 through 4).
cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) - total score
cdes.definitionDescription: Value of the sum of all scores recorded, as part of the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS)

cdes.referrences: Hamilton, M. A rating scale for depression. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1960; 23:56-62  The HDRS is in the public domain.

description: Contains data elements which cumulatively rate the participant/subject's level of depression. (Examples of CDEs included: Insomnia; Feelings of Guilt; Agitation; etc.)

Contains data elements related to collection of information pertaining to Outcomes, specifically Hand Held Dynamometry, that is commonly used in ALS clinical research studies. [Examples of CDEs included: Muscle Tested and Able to break]

cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of whether the hand held dynamometry testing was done.
cdes.instructions: Choose one

description: Developed to assess mobility by evaluating the time and degree of assistance required to walk 25 feet

cdes.cdeName: Hauser Ambulation Index grade
cdes.definitionDescription: The graded numeric result from the Ambulation Index, a rating scale developed by Hauser et al (1983), to assess mobility by evaluating the time and degree of assistance required to walk a 25-foot course as quickly and safely as possible, with scores that range from 0 (asymptomatic) to 10 (bedridden).
cdes.permissibleDescription: Asymptomatic, fully active;Walks normally, but reports fatigue that interferes with athletic or other demanding activities;Abnormal gait or episodic imbalance, gait disorder is noticed by family and friends, able to walk 25 feet (8 meters) in 10 seconds or less;Walks independently, able to walk 25 feet in 20 seconds or less;Requires unilateral support (cane or single crutch) to walk, walks 25 feet in 20 seconds or less;Requires bilateral support (canes, crutches, or walker) and walks 25 feet in 20 seconds or less, or requires unilateral support but needs more than 20 seconds to walk 25 feet;Requires bilateral support and more than 20 seconds to walk 25 feet, may use wheelchair* on occasion;Walking limited to several steps with bilateral support, unable to walk 25 feet, may use wheelchair* for most activities;Restricted to wheelchair, able to transfer self independently;Restricted to wheelchair, unable to transfer self independently;
cdes.instructions: *The use of a wheelchair may be determined by lifestyle and motivation. It is expected that patients in Grade 7 will use a wheelchair more frequently then those in Grades 5 or 6. Assignment of a grade in the range of 5 to 7, however, is determined by the patient’s ability to walk a given distance, and not by the extent to which the patient uses a wheelchair.
cdes.referrences:
Hauser SL, Dawson DM, Lehrich JR, Beal MF, Kevy SV, Propper RD, Mills JA,Weiner HL. Intensive immunosuppression in progressive multiple sclerosis. A randomized, threearm study of high-dose intravenous cyclophosphamide, plasma exchange, and ACTH. N
Engl J Med. 1983 Jan 27;308(4):173-80.

cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of whether the participant/subject experienced a headache on a particular day.

cdes.cdeName: Diary day migraine indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of whether the participant/subject thought the headache was a migraine.
cdes.instructions: A migraine is defined as pain in the head that includes at least 2 or more of the following features (1. throbbing; 2. pain in front, side, or back of head; 3. moderate or severe pain; 4. worsens with activity) AND 1 or more of the following 2 associated symptoms (1. nausea and/or vomiting; 2. light/sound sensitivity). If yes is answered for Headache or Migraine, complete the appropriate Headache Record CRF (Acute or Preventive) for EACH headache/migraine day.

cdes.definitionDescription: The participant's/subject's typical headache pain severity
cdes.questionText: On average, how bad would you rate the severity of the headaches?
cdes.permissibleDescription: Most of the time I can ignore my headache and continue what I'm doing;My headache makes concentration difficult, but I can perform undemanding tasks;I cannot concentrate nor do much of anything;
cdes.instructions: Choose one. Severity assessment in headache trials is most commonly collected as mild, moderate, severity; however pain severity is most commonly collected using an 11-point scale.  It's unclear which of the two scales is more robust in differentiating active versus placebo or between two active treatments. We strongly recommend the Investigator determine what severity scale is appropriate for his/her trial.

cdes.permissibleDescription: Most of the time I can ignore my headache and continue what I'm doing;My headache makes concentration difficult, but I can perform undemanding tasks;I cannot concentrate nor do much of anything;
cdes.instructions: Severity assessment in headache trials is most commonly collected as mild, moderate, severity; however pain severity is most commonly collected using an 11-point scale.  It's unclear which of the two scales is more robust in differentiating active versus placebo or between two active treatments. We would recommend the use of both scales for future Preventive trials.

description: The HImQ is a 16-item, self-administered questionnaire used to measure pain and activity limitations from headache, though not specifically migraine, over a 3-month recall period.

cdes.instructions: Please answer the questions about headaches you have had in the last three months.  Answer in number of days

cdes.instructions: Choose all that apply.

description: The Headache Impact TestTM (HIT-6TM) is a tool that measures the impact headaches, though not specifically migraine, have on a person's ability to function on the job, at home, at school, and in social situations.
This instrument assesses the prevalence of migraine and patterns of migraine treatment.

cdes.instructions: For Questions 46-50, please answer on average for the day or days you were at work in the last two weeks and were not feeling well.  Think specifically about how the most important tasks you do and the tasks you do most often were affected.
cdes.referrences: Copyright permission from Dr. Richard Lipton, Yale University

description: The Headache Needs Assessment Survey (HANA) is a brief, self-administered questionnaire that assess two dimensions of the impact of migraine: frequency and bothersomeness. This instrument has seven questions with the corresponding subscales: Anxiety/Worry, Depression/Discouragement, Self-control, Energy, function/Work, Family/Social Activities, and Overall Impact.

crfModuleGuideline: Headache Patient Reported Outcomes Guidelines - Acute Therapies
description: Contains recommended acute therapy outcome measures that are summarized in the International Headache Society (HIS) Guidelines for controlled trials of drugs in migraine- Third edition published by the IHS Committee on Clinical Trials in Migraine.

crfModuleGuideline: Headache Patient Reported Outcomes Guidelines - Preventive Therapies
description: Contains recommended preventive therapy outcome measures that are summarized in the International Headache Society (HIS) Guidelines for controlled trials of drugs in migraine- Third edition published by the IHS Committee on Clinical Trials in Migraine.

Headminder Concussion Resolution Index

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Child Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Child Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Child Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Child Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Child Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Current Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Current Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Current Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Current Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Current Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Retrospective Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Retrospective Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Retrospective Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Retrospective Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

cdes.instructions: For each problem, please rate your child based on the 4 weeks prior to the injury using the scale below.

crfModuleGuideline: Health and Behavior Inventory (HBI) Parent Retrospective Version
description: The HBI consists of 20 items that measure the frequency of post-concussive symptoms. There are three versions of the inventory - Child, Parent Current Version and Parent Retrospective Version. The Parent Retrospective Version is used for rating pre-injury symptoms retrospectively.

description: The CDC's 14-item HRQoL survey allows subjects to rate their overall health status and the influence of various symptoms on their daily activities. The HRQOL-14 is comprised of three different modules including the Healthy Day core questions, the Activity Limitations module , and Healthy Days Symptoms module.

Developed in Canada, 2002. It has 25 items and 5 subscales which include interpersonal/social consequences; worries and concerns; intrapersonal/emotional; secrecy; and quest for normality. Child (8 years - 15 years) self-report and parent proxy scales each take approximately 15 minutes to complete.

cdes.cdeName: Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) - general health scale
cdes.definitionDescription: The Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) assessment addressing general health.
cdes.questionText: Would you say that in general your health is
cdes.instructions: Instruction to test adminstrator - Please read these possible responses to participant:  Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair, or Poor   Do not read these responses to participant:  Don't know/not sure or Refused
cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) - poor physical health days last 30 days count
cdes.definitionDescription: The Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) assessment addressing the number of days of poor physical health during the past 30 days.
cdes.instructions: Record the number of days using two digits
cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) - poor mental health days last 30 days count
cdes.definitionDescription: The Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) assessment addressing the number of days of poor mental health, including stress, depression, and problems with emotions, during the past 30 days.
cdes.questionText: Now thinking about your mental health, which includes stress, depression, and problems with emotions, for how many days during the past 30 days was your mental health not good?
cdes.instructions: Record the number of days using two digits.  If Q2 and Q3 =  None  (88), then skip Q4 and end questionnaire
cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) - mental physical health prevents activity days last 30 days count
cdes.definitionDescription: The Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) assessment addressing the number of days of poor mental health that prevented usual activities, such as self-care, work, or recreation, during the past 30 days.
cdes.instructions: Record the number of days using two digits
cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.

cdes.instructions: Record the number of days using two digits
cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.

cdes.definitionDescription: The Healthy Days Core Module (CDC HRQOL) assessment addressing the number of days of poor mental health, including stress, depression, and problems with emotions, during the past 30 days.
cdes.questionText: Now thinking about your mental health, which includes stress, depression, and problems with emotions, for how many days during the past 30 days was your mental health not good?
cdes.instructions: Record the number of days using two digits.  If Q2 and Q3 =  None  (88), then skip Q4 and end questionnaire
cdes.referrences: Ronen GM, Ronen, DL, Streiner, PR, & the Canadian Pediatric Epilepsy Network. Health-related Quality of Life in Children with Epilepsy: Development and Validation of Self-report and Parent Proxy Measures. Epilepsia. 2003; 44: 598-612.

cdes.instructions: Record the number of days using two digits
